thread.title: St. Petersburg's pier could be demolished within months

title: St. Petersburg's pier could be demolished within months
text:
St. Petersburg's pier could be demolished within months Caption New St. Pete Pier design Rogers and Partners/ASD/KSLA This concept art is of The Pier Park by Rogers and Partners/ASD/KSLA. This is the top-ranked design chosen by the Pier Selection Committee on April 23, 2015 for the new St. Petersburg Pier. This concept art is of The Pier Park by Rogers and Partners/ASD/KSLA. This is the top-ranked design chosen by the Pier Selection Committee on April 23, 2015 for the new St. Petersburg Pier. (Rogers and Partners/ASD/KSLA) Caption New St. Petersburg Pier design Rogers and Partners/ASD/KSLA This concept art is of The Pier Park by Rogers and Partners/ASD/KSLA. This is the top-ranked design chosen by the Pier Selection Committee on April 23, 2015 for the new St. Petersburg Pier. This concept art is of The Pier Park by Rogers and Partners/ASD/KSLA. This is the top-ranked design chosen by the Pier Selection Committee on April 23, 2015 for the new St. Petersburg Pier. (Rogers and Partners/ASD/KSLA) Demolition of St. Petersburg's downtown, inverted pyramid-shaped pier is imminent 
Demolition of St. Petersburg's downtown, inverted pyramid-shaped pier is imminent. 8 
The Tampa Bay Times reports the U.S. Army Corps of Engineers said it could issue a permit to tear down the 1973 structure as early as this week. 
The City Council approved $5.2 million for initial work on a replacement project and a construction fence went up. Conceptual design for new St. Pete Pier 
This concept design was ranked as the top choice by the St. Pete Pier Selection Committee on April 23, 2015. 
This concept design was ranked as the top choice by the St. Pete Pier Selection Committee on April 23, 2015. See more videos 
But demolition plans were brought to an abrupt halt when the corps said St. Petersburg needed its permission to tear down the entire structure because it spans a body of water. Additionally, a permit couldn't be issued before an agreement had been signed by the corps, the city and the state historic preservation office. That process is now complete. 
Demolition is expected to take six months. 
Information from: Tampa Bay Times (St. Petersburg, Fla.), http://www.tampabay.com.
